captions.text:
The Yakuza series is officially over and Kazuma
Kiryu has disco stomped his last jawbone into

rice pudding, but how could the adventure
ever truly be over in Kamurocho, the city

whose most famous local dish is the knuckle
sandwich, whose streets are covered with so

many shards of broken teeth the district is
frequently mistaken for a zen garden.

Judgment is the new Yakuza spin-off with all
new characters and all new shitty title.

And look, Sega, speaking as someone who dry
heaves when they see unnecessary colons, in

this case no one would&#39;ve minded if you&#39;d
called it Yakuza: Judgment.

What with it playing exactly like most Yakuza
games, a bizarre mix of sightseeing, restaurant

patronage and massively overblown bicycle
fencing contests over the slightest miscommunication,

I worry that most casual Yakuza fans wouldn&#39;t
even realise that it&#39;s the new Yakuza game

just from looking at the title, although they
might have a little argument over whether

or not you&#39;re supposed to spell it with an
E. Oh, but we couldn&#39;t have called it Yahtzu,
Yakuzee.
I mean, Yakuza, Yahtzee.

We&#39;re telling an all new story with all new
characters and the protagonist isn&#39;t a Yakuza
at all.

True, but in fairness, his best pal is a Yakuza,
and so is one of his father figures, and he

spends most of his time hanging around Yakuza,
and can&#39;t walk fifty yards without having
to beat up another clutch of the fuckers.

I&#39;m guessing this is what they call a &quot;gradual
weaning process.&quot;

It&#39;s true, though, the main character Takayuki
Yagami is not a Yakuza.

He doesn&#39;t even wear a disco suit, he wears
a leather jacket and the world&#39;s least comfortable
looking jeans.

But I&#39;m pretty sure that the only reason he
isn&#39;t a Yakuza is because he couldn&#39;t fit
it in alongside his sixteen other jobs.

He&#39;s a private detective, right, who is also
a lawyer.

And at various other times works as a bodyguard,
a locksmith, and a food critic, that last

one because most of the side content revolves
around making friends with as many random

people around Kamurocho as you can and Kamurocho
seems to be almost exclusively populated by
restaurant employees.

Oh yes, and he&#39;s also a kung fu master, but
that&#39;s not really worth mentioning.

In Kamurocho, if you can&#39;t kick with the force
of a pneumatic hammer you officially qualify
to use the disabled parking spaces.

So yeah, probably wasn&#39;t possible to squeeze
Yakuza duties in between his nineteen community
college courses.
The emphasis is on private detective.

Yagami&#39;s leaning into that stereotype like
an inflatable tube man in a strong wind.

He&#39;s forever short on cash, lives in his back
alley office and walks the mean streets monologuing

to himself, although this is still a Yakuza
game so instead of being seduced by mysterious

hotties he takes giggly teenagers to the arcade
to play on the ufo catchers.

And in his capacity as a detective he gets
drawn into a larger intrigue by a series of

mysterious murders that appear to be targeting
the Yakuza.

Although it could be a coincidence &#39;cos this
is Kamurocho and you can&#39;t fucking turn around
without scuffing up a Yakuza&#39;s trouser leg.

And subsequently getting your internal organs
punched out your mouth.

Yagami&#39;s backstory involves carrying around
a big pile of guilt for getting someone off

a murder charge who later did murder for realsies,
but apparently it wasn&#39;t the murdering in

itself that shocked him, going by the way
he does combat.

Yes, it&#39;s the familiar delirious union of
face and convenient nearby solid objects that

you&#39;ve come to expect from Yakuza combat,
just as high-energy and blatantly unsurvivable

as ever, so those people at SEGA who said
the gameplay was going to be different now
were talking out of their implied second buttholes.

I mean, it&#39;s even got the switching between
different fighting styles from Yakuza Zero,
but only two instead of three.

And any mathematician will tell you that one
fewer than zero goes into negatives.

But I guess they didn&#39;t mean combat when they
said all-new gameplay, Yakuza combat is more

like a convenient fun dispenser the games
keep around for when it thinks you&#39;re getting
too bored with the talky bits.

The actual new gameplay is the various private
detective minigames.

So there&#39;s tailing people, in which our six
foot bad hair having detective hero dressed

like he tried to put on his kid&#39;s costume
for the school production of Grease gets to
try to go unnoticed.

And there&#39;s a thing where we track our gaze
across a crime scene looking for pieces of

evidence, and a thing where we have to pick
the right bit of evidence to prove whatever
point we&#39;re trying to make.

It&#39;s all very Phoenix Wright inspired, in
that neither property has the slightest idea

how legal defense actually works, and there&#39;s
even a couple of bits where Judgment directly

references Phoenix Wright, possibly in an
attempt to play the &quot;It&#39;s a homage, not a
ripoff&quot; card.

I already said Judgment sells itself short
with its title but Yakuza games always sell
themselves short.

I enjoy sticking a gumball machine up a well-dressed
man&#39;s nose, but my live-in gimp doesn&#39;t, they

enjoy completionist sidequesting and dating
simulators and might have enjoyed those parts

of Judgment if it weren&#39;t for all the gumball
machine nasal surgery getting in the way.

And while the bizarre mix of tones and gameplay
styles is part of the quirky identity of the

Yakuza series, it also means that none of
the individual mechanics have room to grow.

The detective mechanics just don&#39;t have enough
depth for my liking.
Tailing?

Yeah, you just duck behind something every
time your target stops.

Get the fuck outta here with this Assassin&#39;s
Creed 3 shit, I&#39;m an expert.

And as for the Phoenix Wright stuff, it only
seems to happen once in a blue moon and when

they do they don&#39;t make me feel clever the
way detectivey bits should.

&quot;Hm, which of these pieces of evidence indicates
that the victim was felt up by Noel Edmonds
in a lift?&quot;
Yagami asks himself.
And there&#39;s only three choices.

A receipt, a photo of a surprised dog, and
a piece of paper saying &quot;I felt up the victim
in a lift, signed, Noel Edmonds.&quot;

Maybe it gets deeper toward the end of the
game.

I wouldn&#39;t know, I kind of stopped before
then.

The side stuff had distracted me even more
than it usually does in Yakuza games because

I just wasn&#39;t that interested in the main
plot.
Played one Yakuza main plot, played &#39;em all.

I&#39;m going to assume that the innocent young
person we&#39;re defending for the sake of justice

will turn out to be the victim of a conspiracy
orchestrated by a very smug older man but

it won&#39;t be the kind of villainy that can&#39;t
eventually be sorted out with a massive great
fist fight on the Millennium Tower.

I think what I&#39;m finding in this post-Kazuma
Kiryu world is that Yakuza kinda needs him,
or somebody like him.

Someone who can be effortlessly cool just
by standing there with his retro suit and

his face like the front of a parked Securicor
van.

He was the anchor that a game like Yakuza
needs.

with all its insane combat, twisting plot
and wacky side content, he stood in the middle

of it like a brick wall in a raging stream,
one that&#39;s not above occasionally prancing

around with a ukulele in a karaoke video to
amuse the children.

In contrast, Yagami feels inconsistent, and
too much like he&#39;s trying too hard to project

an image of coolness that a middle-aged dad
pictures in their mind&#39;s eye as they walk
around a consumer electronics shop.
